steps.title: Open your spreadsheet in Microsoft Excel.
steps.content: Open your spreadsheet in Microsoft Excel. You can usually do this by double-clicking the file name on your computer.

steps.title: Highlight the text you want to format.
steps.content: Highlight the text you want to format. You can select an entire cell, multiple cells, or just some of the text within a single cell. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Press Ctrl+5.
steps.content: Press Ctrl + 5 . The selected text now appears crossed-out like this . [3] X Research source To remove this effect, select the text, and then use the keyboard shortcut once more. You may need to use ⌘ Command + ↑ + X on some computers instead of Ctrl + 5 .

steps.title: Open your spreadsheet in Microsoft Excel.
steps.content: Open your spreadsheet in Microsoft Excel. You can usually do this by double-clicking the file name on your computer.

steps.title: Highlight the cells containing text you want to format.
steps.content: Highlight the cells containing text you want to format. If you only want to use strikethrough on some of the text within a cell, see this method instead.

steps.title: Right-click the highlighted area.
steps.content: Right-click the highlighted area. A menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Format Cells.
steps.content: Click Format Cells . The Format Cells dialog box will appear.

steps.title: Click the Font tab.
steps.content: Click the Font tab. It’s near the top of the dialog box.

steps.title: Check the box next to “Strikethrough.”
steps.content: Check the box next to “Strikethrough.” It’s in the “Effects” section.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . This crosses-out the values of the selected cells. The text within the cells now appears crossed-out like this . To remove this effect, return to the Format Cells dialog box, remove the check mark from "Strikethrough," and then click OK .
